subject: Re: [junit] Re: JUnit bug for XML testing?
msgSnippet: ... As much as I wish JDepend did identify classes that contain bugs, it s really more useful as a Java package dependency analyzer.  It reports design quality
messageBody:
Vladimir Bossicard wrote:

> > I am in charge of getting a test
> > framework written for an application with over 200K lines of code that does
> > not have a single test case yet. Yikes! It is very confusing about how to
> > start and how to set up an application level test suite that will touch all
> > the classes.
>
> <snip>

>
> - by analysing your code and report some metrics (complexity,
> inheritence, coupling...), you may be able to guess the classes that are
> the mose likely to be bugged (have a look at JDepend from Mike Clark)
>

As much as I wish JDepend did identify classes that contain bugs, it's really
more useful as a Java package dependency analyzer. It reports design quality
metrics in terms of coupling and stability of packages, rather than classes. It
helps to subjectively analyze software layers, expressed in packages, to ensure
that low-abstraction, instable packages depend only on high-abstraction, stable
packages.

From the testing perspective, it's usually easier to test classes that aren't
coupled to instable packages. In general, unit testing classes in isolation is
easier when those classes have dependencies on abstractions (interfaces) that can
easily be mocked.
